channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Remembering former Rep. Charles Rangel, who has died at 94
item.description: The Democrat represented a New York City district including the historically Black neighborhood of Harlem for nearly 50 years.

item.title: A longtime national security adviser weighs in on recent NSC firings
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with former national intelligence official Richard Clarke about the changes at the National Security Council.

item.title: Grant funding that helps local governments tackle homelessness is at risk
item.description: An effort to slash federal funding to Democrat-led cities with policies the Trump administration disagrees with is being challenged in court. Advocates say the cuts could hurt homelessness services.

item.title: Jaguar conservation effort arms ranchers with cameras -- and pays them for photos
item.description: The U.S. needs more jaguars. One organization has a unique approach to making that happen, as Vox environmental correspondent Benji Jones explains.

item.title: In the Pacific Northwest, tiny, old fire trucks from Japan have a big following
item.description: Kei trucks are tiny trucks shipped from Japan. In the last 10 years, these trucks and vans have become more popular on American farms and cities as utility vehicles.

item.title: In 'What Will People Think?,' a Palestinian American woman must hide her stand-up comedy career
item.description: Sara Hamdan discusses her debut novel What Will People Think?, a story about a Palestinian American woman learning to chase her dreams and break cultural expectations.

item.title: How Trump's effort to move a federal office out of D.C. went in his 1st term
item.description: President Trump set an April 14 deadline for federal agency reorganization plans, suggesting relocating offices out of D.C. to save money. But an agency move to Colorado in Trump's first term failed.

item.title: How federal cuts are affecting school lunches at one Louisiana school
item.description: A program that brings farm fresh foods to schools in Louisiana was cut by the Trump administration. Now some local lawmakers are pushing to get it back.

item.title: Throughline: The birth of the modern federal civil service
item.description: The hosts of the Throughline podcast bring us the story of how a presidential assassination gave rise to the modern federal civil service.

item.title: Colorado's rape kit backlog is a barrier to investigations and arrests
item.description: A nationwide backlog in rape kit testing was largely solved in 2018. But Colorado has fallen behind again due to a corrupt investigator. Progress to catch up will be slow.
